title: Parking warden 'watches and waits' to fine drivers at empty car park on a Sunday
text:

A parking warden sparked outrage after fining an unsuspecting driver in an empty car park on a wet Sunday afternoon.

A motorist who watched the scene said the warden "watched and waited" to catch out visitors at Grimsby's Fishing Heritage Centre.

The North East Lincolnshire Council parking warden is said to have “waited 20 minutes” to issue a ticket in an “almost empty car park” last Sunday at 12.30pm.

The visitor had parked up outside the Fishing Heritage Centre with a teenage boy, Grimsby Live reports.

They had reportedly bought a pay-and-display parking ticket and made their way into the heritage attraction at Alexandra Dock in Grimsby.

Upon returning to their car, they found a parking ticket fixed to their windscreen.

The outraged motorist who watched the incident said: “I saw a man and boy walk into the Fishing Heritage Centre.

“It was a wet and windy day on Sunday, and they’d clearly planned an indoor activity together.

(Image: Grimsbylive)

“I watched them pay-and-display and walk into the Fishing Heritage Centre.

“I also watched a parking warden wait outside in the rain and cold for 20 minutes just to give them a ticket.

“There was only one or two other cars parked up. It was an almost empty car park. He was clearly watching and waiting to strike.

“It was as if he’d waited for one second past their ticket time to issue a ticket – disgusting.”

Parking tickets in the Fishing Heritage Centre’s car park can cost between £50 and £70, depending on the time of contravention, but a 50 percent discount is applied if paid within 14 days.

The motorist added: “If you can’t park in an almost empty car park for free on a Sunday when it’s chucking it down with rain, what’s the point of coming into Grimsby to go around one of its only attractions?

“Why can’t the council develop a free-for-two-hours policy or make parking free on a Sunday like they have in North Lincolnshire?

(Image: Grimsbylive)

“It would be especially useful in this car park because you’d probably end up with more people coming into town and the Fishing Heritage Centre. They could trial it over Christmas.”

A spokesperson for North East Lincolnshire Council said the council's "need to generate revenues" was a key driver of the policy.

The council statement said: “We always appreciate peoples’ views on such things as parking and are constantly reviewing and looking at the best options to increase footfall to our town centre and the facilities we provide.

“However, we must also balance those decisions out with the need to generate revenues, which is vital if we are to maintain and improve what we have to offer across the whole of North East Lincolnshire.”

(Image: Grimsbylive)

A coach driver was previously fined £50 for parking in the Fishing Heritage Centre's approved "coach-only" space when the car par was deserted.

It was argued that the driver was required to purchase a pay-and-display ticket, but this was later disproven.

The Fishing Heritage Centre provides coach drivers with free parking when dropping off and picking up visitors.

Speaking at the time, the coach driver said: “You shouldn’t have to pay to park when you’re bringing a group of children to be educated in a place like this, you’re only doing your job - it seems a bit unfair.

“I think the council is just clutching at straws trying to get every driver they can now.”
description: The motorist who was fined last Sunday had parked up outside Grimsby's Fishing Heritage Centre after buying a pay-and-display ticket
